label: A_hP4_194_f-001
title: Lonsdaleite (Hexagonal Diamond) Structure
comments:
Hexagonal diamond was named lonsdaleite in honor of \href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kathleen_Lonsdale}{Kathleen Lonsdale}. 
 This structure is related to the \href{current_web_home_dir/A_hP2_194_c-001}{hcp ($A3$) structure} in the same way that \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cF8_227_a-001}{diamond ($A4$)} is related to the \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cF4_225_a-001}{fcc lattice ($A1$)}. 
 It can also be obtained from \href{current_web_home_dir/AB_hP4_186_b_b-001}{wurtzite ($B4$)} by replacing both the Zn and S atoms by carbon. 
 The ``ideal'' structure, where the nearest-neighbor environment of each atom is the same as in diamond, is achieved when we take $c/a=\sqrt{8/3}$ and $z_{1}=1/16$. 
 Alternatively, we can take $z_{1}=3/16$, in which case the origin is at the center of a C-C bond aligned in the [0001] direction. 
 When $z_{1}=0$ this structure becomes a set of graphitic sheets, but not true \href{current_web_home_dir/A_hP4_194_bc-001}{hexagonal graphite ($A9$)}, as the stacking differs. 
 (Yoshiasa, 2003) does not have an ICSD entry for Lonsdaleite, so we use the one provided for (Ownby, 1992).
